abstract.p: Patricia Brooks reviews Bailey's Backyard restaurant in Ridgefield, Conn (M)

block.p: THE proprietors of Bailey's Backyard in Ridgefield have done about as much as they can to decorate tiny storefront space attractively, even using white picket fencing along each pale taupe-painted wall to suggest al fresco dining. (Actually there are a couple of tables outdoors facing the street.)

The American-style dinner menu augured well, though we wondered how so many different dishes (about a dozen entrees) with diverse ingredients could be prepared in what looked to be a small kitchen. But the big question for diners was how well they could do it.

THE proprietors of Bailey's Backyard in Ridgefield have done about as much as they can to decorate tiny storefront space attractively, even using white picket fencing along each pale taupe-painted wall to suggest al fresco dining. (Actually there are a couple of tables outdoors facing the street.)

The American-style dinner menu augured well, though we wondered how so many different dishes (about a dozen entrees) with diverse ingredients could be prepared in what looked to be a small kitchen. But the big question for diners was how well they could do it.
Very well indeed was our first reaction, when a plate of good crusty bread arrived, along with aromatic olive oil, amplified by a zesty dip of sun-dried tomatoes, garlic and rosemary.

Among a quartet of appetizers we were especially pleased with the stuffed marinated portobello mushroom (served with mixed greens in a tease of balsamic vinaigrette), and tempura shrimp (embraced by a light batter, fried and accompanied by a zingy papaya-ginger dipping sauce).

Crispy crawfish cakes, a welcome variation on crab cakes, were very tasty with a generous crawfish presence, despite an excess of breading. The two lightly browned cakes, with tops embroidered by swirls of Creole remoulade sauce, sat on a bed of greens without dressing. A more serious omission, in our view, was in the Southwestern spicy Caesar salad. Though the romaine lettuce leaves were crispy fresh and well-trimmed and the croutons toasty, two key elements were missing: anchovies (apparently banished from most Caesar salads these days) and chipotle (not a whisper of the dried, smoked chile could be detected).

Entrees were a mixed bag. Louisiana grilled shrimp and chorizo, served over red beans and rice, along with braised spinach, proved a winning alliance; the sausage was unusually spicy and satisfying. A variation of this dish was also a lunchtime hit, with a chunk of chorizo skewered into each jumbo shrimp as a base.

Our spiced pork medallions were flavorful and generous in size, but the real star of this ensemble (which also included mashed potatoes) was the sensational sweet-sour rhubarb-cherry chutney that accompanied it. This tangy number stole the show, so good it should be bottled and sold.
We also enjoyed the well-cooked New Zealand grilled rack of lamb, but the excellent chops were undermined by undercooked goat cheese ravioli (admirable filling, but rubbery pasta).

One entree was a fiasco of proportions we haven't experienced at a restaurant in years. The Southern roasted barbecue duck (two large legs and thighs) was so tough (not chewy; tough, tough, tough) that our knife had difficulty breaking the skin. One glance inside and we beckoned the waiter: the interior was bloody and raw. The waiter whisked it away, but when it was returned a few minutes later, it was still one tough bird, almost impossible to penetrate with a knife. The accompanying black-eyed peas (dry), green beans and hush puppies (light, golden and bite-size) couldn't compensate for a disastrous dish.

What better antidote to a ruined course than some comfort food? We found it at lunch with the baked Vermont Cheddar cheese and macaroni, a large casserole bubbling hot, filled to the brim with bead-like ditalini pasta in a cheese-creamy sauce with a crunchy melted Cheddar seal.

Most desserts were out-and-out delicious. Especially so was chocolate explosion: dark chocolate cake layered with outrageously rich fudge and sidecars of house-whipped cream. Chocolate raspberry tuxedo pie, caramelized banana pudding with a vanilla accent, and apple pie were all we could wish for.
Dinner for two, three courses each, came to $64, before tax, tip or drinks. The small wine list, mostly California and West Coast, is well priced, from $19.

Good ATMOSPHERE -- The minuscule space seems airy and agreeable. Noise level: Subdued, conversational. SERVICE -- Friendly, but some staffers are insufficiently trained (''Who gets the salmon? Who gets the duck?''). RECOMMENDED DISHES -- Crispy crawfish cakes, stuffed marinated portobello mushroom, New Zealand grilled rack of lamb, spiced pork medallions, Lousiana grilled shrimp and chorizo. PRICE RANGE -- Lunch entrees $7 to $13, dinner entrees $13 to $24. CREDIT CARDS -- All major cards. HOURS -- 11 a.m.-3 p.m. Monday-Friday, noon-3 p.m. Saturday. 5 to 10 p.m. Monday-Saturday. Closed Sunday. RESERVATIONS -- Recommended. ACCESSIBILITY -- Dining room and restrooms at ground level.
THE RATINGS Extraordinary, Excellent, Very Good, Good, Satisfactory, Fair, Poor.
Ratings reflect the reviewer's reaction to food, ambiance and service, with price taken into consideration. Menu listings and prices are subject to change.
